title: Black outlook at Argos owner
text:
Black outlook at Argos owner Black outlook at Argos owner SHARES in Home Retail Group crashed yesterday as the Argos owner warned of the impact on key Christmas trading from next month’s Black Friday shopping bonanza. PUBLISHED: 21:22,   21:43, Wed, Oct 21, 2015 GETTY Argos has experienced a drop in sales of electrical products such as televisions and tablet computer 
About £200million was wiped from the value of the FTSE 250 group as it sounded a profit alert, claiming the run-up to the festive period had become “less predictable” with bargain-hunters set to target their spending on heavy promotions during the US-inspired 24-hour discount shopping event on November 27. 
Argos has also experienced a drop in sales of electrical products such as televisions and tablet computers and is making a big investment transforming itself from a catalogue-based to a digitalfocused business with the launch of its Fast Track collection and delivery service. 
These factors mean annual profits at Home Retail, which also runs the DIY chain Homebase, are likely to be below current forecasts of between £115million and £140million. GETTY A £5.6million fall in profits at Argos was offset by a £6.5million uplift at Homebase While we believe a digital future is the correct strategy, we have concerns on its ability to transform its performance. David Jeary CanaccordGenuity 
Home Retail chief executive John Walden, has highlighted shoppers’ addiction to discounts after last year’s Black Friday, which was followed by a drop in demand and led to Argos suffering its worst festive sales for three years. 
Yesterday, he said: “Trading at Argos during this year’s important Christmas season seems less predictable than usual, as both retailers and customers determine whether to repeat last year’s unusual Black Friday patterns. 
“We’ve certainly planned to participate in Black Friday and we’re expecting it to be big. Our uncertainty is just about the extent and about the patterns over the course of the season.” 
Half-year sales at Home Retail dropped 2 per cent to £2.63billion but group pre-tax profit increased by 10 per cent to £34.1million. GETTY Half-year sales at Home Retail dropped 2 per cent to £2.63billion 
A £5.6million fall in profits at Argos was offset by a £6.5million uplift at Homebase, where demand for major items such as kitchens, bathrooms and furniture boosted sales at stores open at least a year by 5.6 per cent. 
David Jeary, retail analyst at broker CanaccordGenuity, said: “While we believe a digital future is the correct strategy, we have concerns on its ability to transform its performance. 
"Not only was Argos late to digital but competition is intense, with some others, arguably, better.” 
Shares fell 23¾p to 126p Related articles
